title: How to Make an Easter Egg Wreath

methods.name: Making a Simple Plastic Egg Wreath

steps.headline: Get a pack of hinged plastic Easter eggs and pop them open.
steps.description: There are lots of plastic Easter eggs on the market. Some of them come apart completely into 2 halves, while others are connected by a small hinge, like a box lid. You want to get the type that are connected by a hinge, like a box lid. Pop the eggs open by squeezing the seams. You need enough eggs to assemble into a ring. Plan on using about 12 to 15 eggs.

steps.headline: Connect the top of your first egg to the bottom of your second egg.
steps.description: You've probably noticed that the eggs have a skinny top half and a fat bottom half--just like real eggs! Take the top half from your first egg and snap it onto the bottom half from your second egg. Rotate the eggs so that the half-shells lay straight. If you were to set the eggs down on a table, they should all be touching the flat surface.

steps.headline: Continue to connect the eggs until you get the length you want.
steps.description: Pick up another egg and snap the wider bottom shell onto the narrower top shell from the second egg. Continue to connect eggs in this manner until you can curve them into a ring. How many eggs you use depends on the size of wreath you want. The more eggs you use, the bigger the wreath will be. For a permanent wreath, coat the seams with super glue before you connect the shells.

steps.headline: Snap together the first and last eggs to complete the ring.
steps.description: Once your row of eggs is the length you want it to be, snap the top shell from the last egg onto the bottom shell from the first egg.

steps.headline: Thread a ribbon through the wreath to make a hanging loop.
steps.description: Cut a 20 in (51 cm) piece of ribbon. Poke 1 end of the ribbon through the middle of the wreath, then tie the ends together to make a hanging loop. For a fancier wreath, tie another ribbon into a big bow around the bottom of the wreath. You can hang this wreath anywhere you want. It is completely waterproof!

steps.headline: Cut the inside out of a paper plate to create a ring.
steps.description: Find a paper plate, then poke a hole in the middle. Stick scissors into the hole and cut towards the rim. Cut around the inside edge of the rim to create a ring. Keep the ring and discard the rest. Alternatively, you can cut a ring out of a sheet of cardstock. The paper plate can be any side you want it to be. The actual wreath will be about 4 to 8 in (10 to 20 cm) bigger than the plate, depending on the placement of the eggs.

steps.headline: Choose 2 to 3 colors or patterns of Spring-themed scrapbooking paper.
steps.description: You can use solid-colored cardstock or patterned scrapbooking paper, which is thinner. Choose spring or Easter-themed patterns, such as polka dots, stripes, chicks, or spring flowers. Color-wise, you can go with pastels or bright colors. Avoid colors that are too dark. Choose patterns that you might see on an actual Easter egg.

steps.headline: Use an egg-shaped cookie cutter to trace eggs onto patterned paper.
steps.description: Get 2 to 3 sheets of paper in different colors and/or patterns. Draw 4 in (10 cm) tall egg shapes by hand, or use 4 in (10 cm) tall egg-shaped cookie cutter as a stencil instead. How many eggs you trace depends on the size of your ring--you need enough eggs to cover the ring. Use a pencil so that you can erase the marks later. If you are working on patterned paper, draw on the back.

steps.headline: Cut the eggs out with scissors.
steps.description: Alternatively, you can use a craft blade; make your cuts small and be sure to work on top of a cutting mat. If you have any pencil marks left over, take a moment to erase them.

steps.headline: Glue the eggs side by side to the ring.
steps.description: The bottom (wider) ends of the eggs should be facing into the ring. The top (smaller) ends of the eggs should be facing away from the ring. Overlap the eggs onto the ring enough so that you can't see the ring anymore. You can scoot the eggs closer towards the middle of the ring to create a smaller wreath. A glue stick will work just fine for this, but you can use tacky glue too.

steps.headline: Decorate the wreath with ribbons and glitter, if desired.
steps.description:
Cut a piece of ribbon and tie it into a bow. Secure it to the top or bottom of your wreath with tacky glue, hot glue, or a glue dot. Here are some more decorating ideas:
Draw designs with glitter glue. If you don't have glitter glue, use regular glue, then sprinkle glitter on top. Embellish the eggs with buttons, rhinestones, or sequins. Outline designs with metallic pens and markers.

steps.headline: Glue a loop of ribbon to the top of the wreath so that you can hang it.
steps.description: Flip the wreath over so that you can see the back. Cut a 12 to 24 in (30 to 61 cm) piece of ribbon, then bring the ends together to form a loop. Secure the ends to the top of the wreath with hot glue, tacky glue, or a glue dot.

steps.headline: Use the ribbon loop to hang the wreath.
steps.description: Flip the wreath back over so that the design part is facing you. Find a hook, nail, or doorknob to hang the wreath from, then slip the ribbon loop over it. Do not hang this wreath outside, or the paper will get ruined.

methods.name: Making a Traditional Easter Egg Wreath

steps.headline: Choose a wreath to use as your base.
steps.description: For a rustic or natural-looking wreath, a grapevine wreath will work the best. If you want to cover the entire wreath with Easter eggs, however, a Styrofoam wreath will work better. Choose a wreath that's a little smaller than what you want the final wreath to be. The items you add on top will make it look bigger.

steps.headline: Hot glue moss to the front of a grapevine wreath to create a natural look.
steps.description: Purchase a bag of moss from the craft store, then hot glue tufts to the front of the wreath. Leave the back and sides of the wreath bare so that the visible grapevine will give it some texture! Alternatively, you can cover the wreath with Easter grass. This will make it look more like an Easter basket. If you are using a Styrofoam wreath, consider wrapping burlap or satin ribbon around it to hide the foam. Hot glue the ends of the ribbon down so that it doesn't come off.

steps.headline: Hot glue plastic Easter eggs to the wreath.
steps.description: Here is where you can get really creative! If you go to a craft store, you'll find all sorts of plastic Easter eggs, from the traditional brightly-colored ones to ones that are speckled to look like real bird eggs. You can hot glue as many eggs as you want to your wreath. If you covered your wreath with moss, leave some of the moss showing between the eggs for a more natural look. Don’t add anything to the sides. If you used a Styrofoam wreath, consider using enough eggs to cover the entire wreath, including the sides. Play around with different egg sizes. Make them point all in the same direction or in different directions. You can use real eggs, but you will have to empty and clean them first.

steps.headline: Fill the gaps between the eggs with sprigs of flowers, if desired.
steps.description: If you left some space between your eggs, you might want to fill them in with small sprigs of silk flowers. This will look especially nice if you used moss on a grapevine wreath. Small flowers, such as chamomile, baby’s breath, or lavender will look the nicest. Alternatively, you can use sprigs of greenery, such as leaves or ferns, instead.

steps.headline: Make a bow out of wired ribbon, then secure it to the wreath, if desired.
steps.description: It would be best to secure the bow to the wreath with a piece of floral wire. This way, you can easily pull it off and re-use it. Alternatively, you can hot glue the bow to the wreath. Most people like to place their bow at the top or bottom of the wreath, but you can place yours at an angle for a unique look! Cut the ends of the ribbon into angles or notches, then seal them with a flame to prevent fraying.

steps.headline: Add a ribbon hanging loop, if desired.
steps.description: The easiest way to hang a wreath is to fit a wreath hanger over your door, then hang the wreath from the large hook. If you don't want to use one of those, however, cut a 12 to 24 in (30 to 61 cm) piece of ribbon, thread it through the middle of your wreath, then tie the ends together to make a loop. If you made your wreath from Styrofoam and plastic eggs, you can hang it outside, but other types of materials may not be waterproof and should be hung indoors.

text:
Making a Simple Plastic Egg Wreath Get a pack of hinged plastic Easter eggs and pop them open. There are lots of plastic Easter eggs on the market. Some of them come apart completely into 2 halves, while others are connected by a small hinge, like a box lid. You want to get the type that are connected by a hinge, like a box lid. Pop the eggs open by squeezing the seams. You need enough eggs to assemble into a ring. Plan on using about 12 to 15 eggs. Connect the top of your first egg to the bottom of your second egg. You've probably noticed that the eggs have a skinny top half and a fat bottom half--just like real eggs! Take the top half from your first egg and snap it onto the bottom half from your second egg. Rotate the eggs so that the half-shells lay straight. If you were to set the eggs down on a table, they should all be touching the flat surface. Continue to connect the eggs until you get the length you want. Pick up another egg and snap the wider bottom shell onto the narrower top shell from the second egg. Continue to connect eggs in this manner until you can curve them into a ring. How many eggs you use depends on the size of wreath you want. The more eggs you use, the bigger the wreath will be. For a permanent wreath, coat the seams with super glue before you connect the shells. Snap together the first and last eggs to complete the ring. Once your row of eggs is the length you want it to be, snap the top shell from the last egg onto the bottom shell from the first egg. Thread a ribbon through the wreath to make a hanging loop. Cut a 20 in (51 cm) piece of ribbon. Poke 1 end of the ribbon through the middle of the wreath, then tie the ends together to make a hanging loop. For a fancier wreath, tie another ribbon into a big bow around the bottom of the wreath. You can hang this wreath anywhere you want. It is completely waterproof! Making a Paper Wreath Cut the inside out of a paper plate to create a ring. Find a paper plate, then poke a hole in the middle. Stick scissors into the hole and cut towards the rim. Cut around the inside edge of the rim to create a ring. Keep the ring and discard the rest. Alternatively, you can cut a ring out of a sheet of cardstock. The paper plate can be any side you want it to be. The actual wreath will be about 4 to 8 in (10 to 20 cm) bigger than the plate, depending on the placement of the eggs. Choose 2 to 3 colors or patterns of Spring-themed scrapbooking paper. You can use solid-colored cardstock or patterned scrapbooking paper, which is thinner. Choose spring or Easter-themed patterns, such as polka dots, stripes, chicks, or spring flowers. Color-wise, you can go with pastels or bright colors. Avoid colors that are too dark. Choose patterns that you might see on an actual Easter egg. Use an egg-shaped cookie cutter to trace eggs onto patterned paper. Get 2 to 3 sheets of paper in different colors and/or patterns. Draw 4 in (10 cm) tall egg shapes by hand, or use 4 in (10 cm) tall egg-shaped cookie cutter as a stencil instead. How many eggs you trace depends on the size of your ring--you need enough eggs to cover the ring. Use a pencil so that you can erase the marks later. If you are working on patterned paper, draw on the back. Cut the eggs out with scissors. Alternatively, you can use a craft blade; make your cuts small and be sure to work on top of a cutting mat. If you have any pencil marks left over, take a moment to erase them. Glue the eggs side by side to the ring. The bottom (wider) ends of the eggs should be facing into the ring. The top (smaller) ends of the eggs should be facing away from the ring. Overlap the eggs onto the ring enough so that you can't see the ring anymore. You can scoot the eggs closer towards the middle of the ring to create a smaller wreath. A glue stick will work just fine for this, but you can use tacky glue too. Decorate the wreath with ribbons and glitter, if desired. Cut a piece of ribbon and tie it into a bow. Secure it to the top or bottom of your wreath with tacky glue, hot glue, or a glue dot. Here are some more decorating ideas:
Draw designs with glitter glue. If you don't have glitter glue, use regular glue, then sprinkle glitter on top. Embellish the eggs with buttons, rhinestones, or sequins. Outline designs with metallic pens and markers. Glue a loop of ribbon to the top of the wreath so that you can hang it. Flip the wreath over so that you can see the back. Cut a 12 to 24 in (30 to 61 cm) piece of ribbon, then bring the ends together to form a loop. Secure the ends to the top of the wreath with hot glue, tacky glue, or a glue dot. Use the ribbon loop to hang the wreath. Flip the wreath back over so that the design part is facing you. Find a hook, nail, or doorknob to hang the wreath from, then slip the ribbon loop over it. Do not hang this wreath outside, or the paper will get ruined. Making a Traditional Easter Egg Wreath Choose a wreath to use as your base. For a rustic or natural-looking wreath, a grapevine wreath will work the best. If you want to cover the entire wreath with Easter eggs, however, a Styrofoam wreath will work better. Choose a wreath that's a little smaller than what you want the final wreath to be. The items you add on top will make it look bigger. Hot glue moss to the front of a grapevine wreath to create a natural look. Purchase a bag of moss from the craft store, then hot glue tufts to the front of the wreath. Leave the back and sides of the wreath bare so that the visible grapevine will give it some texture! Alternatively, you can cover the wreath with Easter grass. This will make it look more like an Easter basket. If you are using a Styrofoam wreath, consider wrapping burlap or satin ribbon around it to hide the foam. Hot glue the ends of the ribbon down so that it doesn't come off. Hot glue plastic Easter eggs to the wreath. Here is where you can get really creative! If you go to a craft store, you'll find all sorts of plastic Easter eggs, from the traditional brightly-colored ones to ones that are speckled to look like real bird eggs. You can hot glue as many eggs as you want to your wreath. If you covered your wreath with moss, leave some of the moss showing between the eggs for a more natural look. Don’t add anything to the sides. If you used a Styrofoam wreath, consider using enough eggs to cover the entire wreath, including the sides. Play around with different egg sizes. Make them point all in the same direction or in different directions. You can use real eggs, but you will have to empty and clean them first. Fill the gaps between the eggs with sprigs of flowers, if desired. If you left some space between your eggs, you might want to fill them in with small sprigs of silk flowers. This will look especially nice if you used moss on a grapevine wreath. Small flowers, such as chamomile, baby’s breath, or lavender will look the nicest. Alternatively, you can use sprigs of greenery, such as leaves or ferns, instead. Make a bow out of wired ribbon, then secure it to the wreath, if desired. It would be best to secure the bow to the wreath with a piece of floral wire. This way, you can easily pull it off and re-use it. Alternatively, you can hot glue the bow to the wreath. Most people like to place their bow at the top or bottom of the wreath, but you can place yours at an angle for a unique look! Cut the ends of the ribbon into angles or notches, then seal them with a flame to prevent fraying. Add a ribbon hanging loop, if desired. The easiest way to hang a wreath is to fit a wreath hanger over your door, then hang the wreath from the large hook. If you don't want to use one of those, however, cut a 12 to 24 in (30 to 61 cm) piece of ribbon, thread it through the middle of your wreath, then tie the ends together to make a loop. If you made your wreath from Styrofoam and plastic eggs, you can hang it outside, but other types of materials may not be waterproof and should be hung indoors.
